We are not currently accepting applications for the Australian Government Graduate Program - Data stream.

Register your interest here to receive updates on new Data Graduate positions as they become available.

What is the Australian Government Graduate Program - Data Stream?

The Australian Government Graduate Program - Data Stream is a program offering recent graduates permanent employment across the Australian Government. The Data Stream is led by the Australian Bureau of Statistics who recruit for data roles on behalf of the Australian Government.

One application for a Data Graduate position gives you access to opportunities across Australia in multiple agencies.

A wide range of data graduate roles will be recruited for, including Data Analysts, Data Scientists and Statistical & Mathematical roles.



Some of the agencies you may be able to work at include:

There are no requirements for any particular degrees or disciplines though graduates who have undertaken data related, statistics and maths subjects are more likely to be successful.



It's quick and easy to register your interest for upcoming positions. Once you have submitted your form, you'll go on our mailing list and we'll notify as soon as we have more information.

Minderoo Foundation is a modern philanthropic organisation. We take on tough, persistent issues with the potential to drive massive change. We incubate ideas and accelerate impact. We push the limits of what is believed possible. Minderoo Foundation is independent, forward thinking and seeks effective, scalable solutions. We are proudly Australian, and one of Asia’s largest philanthropies, with AUD $2 billion committed to a range of global initiatives. Our team comprises over 150 employees across seven locations.
Walk Free is an international human rights group working to accelerate the end of all forms of modern slavery. We combine world class research with engagement with political, business, religious and community leaders and direct implementation through our civil society partners to drive systems change and dismantle the drivers of modern slavery.

Welcome to Aginic, a consultancy where some of the country’s brightest data analysts, engineers, agile coaches, designers, and cloud architects blend their technical skills with a desire to deliver impactful insights that solve business problems.

As part of Mantel Groups ‘house of brands’, our approach is simple; we hire smart people and get out of their way. By focusing on our five principles and not getting caught up in red tape, we trust you to get the job done.

We've built a hybrid approach to working where you can access any (or all!) of our awesome hubs providing a space for collaboration across Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane, Perth, Magnetic island & Auckland (and more to come!) meaning you can choose a work model that works best for you and your individual needs!

We are currently recruiting for Graduate Data Engineer positions across Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane to start in January 2023.

Job Title: , Research Fellow in Edge Computing, School of Computer, Data and Mathematical Sciences
Job Description:
Full-time, fixed term until 30 September 2023
Remuneration: $127,812 to $150,817 p.a.
Parramatta South campus
About Western
Western Sydney University is a modern, forward-thinking, research-led university, located at the heart of Australia’s fastest-growing and economically significant region, Western Sydney. Boasting 11 campuses – many in Western Sydney CBD locations – and more than 200,000 alumni, 49,500 students and 3,500 staff, the University has 14 Schools with an array of well-designed programs and degrees carefully structured to meet the demands of future industry. Western Sydney University is a modern, forward-thinking, research-led university, located at the heart of Australia’s fastest-growing economically significant region, Western Sydney.

Benefits
Western Sydney University has long been identified as a University of the people. We value the contributions made by our staff and recognise that they underpin the enablement of our mission and values. In return, we offer:


The School of Computer, Data and Mathematical Sciences is located in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) Cluster, together with the School of Engineering, Design and Built Environment, the School of Science, the MARCS Institute and the Hawkesbury Institute for the Environment.

The School offers both undergraduate and postgraduate programs, including research programs that combine advanced academic knowledge with real-life training to suit a range of career needs and interests in the following disciplines: Computer Science and Information Technologies, Data Sciences and Mathematics. The School conducts world leading research in main themes including Intelligent Decision Making, Computing for Sustainability and Equality and Foundation, Algorithms and Discovery.

We seek an energetic, forward-thinking, dynamic, and innovative scholar to take on a Postdoctoral Research Fellowship for a full-time, fixed-term role for one year to work on On-Board Federated Learning in Orbital Edge Computing for Space Situational Awareness. The appointed applicant will undertake research in Edge Computing focusing on federated learning and reconfigurable computing.


The successful applicant is expected to be developing a strong international standing and research reputation, have an excellent research background in the field of edge computing and machine learning, have demonstrated track record of publication of high-quality papers in top journals and conferences in the field, and capacity to undertake independent research.

The position is a full-time, fixed term role until 30 September 2023, based at the Parramatta South Campus.

Please refer to the position description for more information.

Academic Level B $127,812 to $150,817 p.a. (comprising Salary of $108,003 to $127,531 p.a., plus Superannuation and Leave Loading)

Job Description:
An exciting opportunity for an energetic and passionate GIS Officer has opened for working out of our Kariong office, NSW. This job is open as a full or part time position with a minimum 24 hours per week.
About the role
Undertake complex map preparation of a high standard for consultancy projects.

Work with a tight knit project team to support each other.

APS Level 6, Ongoing/Non-ongoing
$84,417 - $95,979 + 15.4% super
60017771
The Bureau's Research Program sits within the Science and Innovation Group and is the main driver of world-class science-based innovation in the Bureau of Meteorology aligned with the Group’s R&D Plan 2020-2030. In supporting the Bureau to deliver impactful weather, water, climate, oceans and earth system prediction services, the research contributes to advancing meteorological and earth system sciences in Australia and globally. Research activities cover the broad fields of weather, climate, oceanography, land surface, and earth systems modelling, data set development, process studies, and application development.

The Hydrological Modelling team of the Bureau’s Research Program is seeking to fill the role of Scientist – Hydrologist (APS6). The successful candidate will contribute to the implementation and validation of the future operational continental routing scheme, as well as working with other scientists in the team to model the impact of soil hydrology and groundwater dynamics on the surface runoff generation. The successful candidate will take responsibility of the model verification within the Hydrological Modelling team and will closely collaborate with Hydrological Information and Surface Observations team, which leads the verification work within the section. Contribution to scientific discussions in support of the progression and definition of the Hydrological Modelling team’s main aims would be expected.

Tasks include developing plans to achieve milestones and overseeing their delivery within the designated work packages, including hands-on work on model data assessments, parameterisation of the routing schemes within continental-scale hydrological/land surface models, and if desired undertaking data assimilation experiments together with colleagues across the Research program, using scripting and coding languages (e.g. Python) on the Bureau’s and NCI’s Linux systems.

Where relevant, the Scientist – Hydrologist (APS6) will also contribute to initiatives of broader value to the entire Bureau (e.g. supporting the SIG leadership team with administrative tasks, actively engaging with social groups within the agency).

Job Title: APS 5, 6 (Multiple Classifications) - Geospatial Data Analyst / Geospatial Data Scientist
Job Description:
$78,143 - $97,790 (plus Super)
Russell - ACT
The Role
APS5/6 – Data Analyst

This role will leverage your understanding of statistics, Geospatial Information Systems (GIS), and programming. You will work as part of a team to develop and implement new tools and methodologies that use AGO’s data and GIS more effectively and efficiently. You will work with a range of stakeholders, including AGO’s intelligence analysts, data scientists and capability managers, ensuring your analytics meet user requirements, are rigorous and consistent with AGO’s system environment.

APS5/6 – Data Scientist

This role will leverage your experience in Machine Learning/Artificial Intelligence (ML/AI), data analysis and automation, to assist AGO to derive deeper insights from larger volumes of data, and at a pace that enables decision advantage. You will liaise with a range of stakeholders to evaluate and implement ML/AI technologies that drive innovation and modernise AGO’s analytic practices.

Both roles will support AGO staff to increase their digital and data fluency.


The Australian Geospatial-Intelligence Organisation (AGO) makes a critical contribution to protect the lives and safety of Australians at home and overseas by providing accurate and timely geospatial-intelligence to support decision makers at all levels.

The Data Innovation and Analytics Directorate (DIAD) is a team of highly motivated data specialists who provide analytical support to AGO’s intelligence and production areas. Our vision is to transform analytic workflows, increasing automation and augmentation through the application of data science and machine analytics. We work closely with a range of stakeholders to understand their analytic requirements, and deliver new tools and methodologies that enable them to achieve more efficient and innovative outcomes. We foster a data-driven culture that supports analysts to gain deeper insights from larger volumes of data. We provide opportunities for continuous learning and developing, including funding for tertiary qualifications in machine analytics, and the opportunity to engage with industry and academia.


Successful candidates will be highly motivated, have strong oral and communication skills, with broad knowledge of geospatial data applications and analytical techniques. In addition, they will be able to work both individually and as part of a team, build and maintain productive working relationships with diverse stakeholders, and proactively address skill/knowledge gaps.

They will be resilient problem solvers, willing to engage with ambiguity and are able to harness collective knowledge to optimise outcomes. They will also be possess some of the following:

The Role
Our Intelligence Assessment Analysts and Information Security Technologists possess a mix of specialist skills and abilities that enable them to identify, understand, and disrupt the top cyber threats impacting Australia’s national and economic security.

Analysts and Technologists operate in both classified and unclassified domains, fusing information from a range of sources while collaboratively engaging with government, law enforcement and industry partners.

This challenging work is undertaken in an inclusive and supportive environment and our intelligence plays a vital role in shaping the disruption and mitigation of dynamic and evolving threats.




Our ideal candidate is a curious, collaborative individual who is not afraid of a challenge, and be able to:
Prior experience or skills in cyber security is desirable but not mandatory. Applicants with experience or qualifications in any of the skills, disciplines or platforms listed below are strongly encouraged to apply:

Executive Level 2 (SRS) - Ongoing
$125,053 - $146,999 + 15.4% super
Any Bureau’s State or Territory capital city office
The Bureau's Research Program sits within the Science and Innovation Group and is the main driver of world-class science-based innovation in the Bureau of Meteorology aligned with the Group’s R&D Plan 2020-2030. In supporting the Bureau to deliver impactful weather, water, climate, oceans and earth system prediction services, the research contributes to advancing meteorological and earth system sciences in Australia and globally. Research activities cover the broad fields of weather, climate, oceanography, land surface, and earth systems modelling, data set development, process studies, and application development.

The Hydrological Modelling team of the Bureau’s Research Program is seeking to fill the role of Scientist – Earth System Scientist. The successful candidate will lead novel research into hydrological and land surface dynamics modelling within the Hydrological Modelling team. A particular focus of this role is on the future operational land surface model’s re-parameterisation and verification (vegetation and soil physics) and in particular leading the Hydrological Modelling team’s work on the assimilation of new or novel observations into the land surface scheme. The successful candidate is also expected to contribute to discussions and take in part responsibility of the definition and progression of the Hydrological Modelling team’s main aims, using their understanding of customer needs.

The Earth System Scientist role is to lead relevant work packages within the Hydrological Modelling research program, and collaborate on select projects scientific and technical staff across the Research Program and other Bureau employees, as well as external stakeholders, in particular from the UK MetOffice and UK Centre for Environment and Hydrology. This requires the successful candidate to have experience in liaising effectively with such partners.
Tasks include developing research plans and overseeing their delivery within the designated work packages, including hands-on work on Earth observation data assessments, parameterisation of the land surface schemes within continental-scale hydrological/land surface models, and undertaking data assimilation experiments together with colleagues across the Research program, using scripting and coding languages (e.g. Python) on the Bureau’s and NCI’s Linux systems.

Where relevant, the Earth System Scientist will also contribute or lead strategic initiatives of broader value to the entire Bureau (e.g. the National Satellite Program on Earth Observations).

Job Title: Data Scientist - Procan Cancer Data Science (CDS)
Job Description:
Make an important contribution to the health of future generations through medical research
Work with a world-leading, independent medical research institute
Located in Westmead—Sydney’s and Australia’s foremost biomedical research precinct
Children’s Medical Research Institute (CMRI) was Australia’s first dedicated paediatric research facility and is now one of the world’s most highly regarded independent medical research organisations. Our research focuses on the four key areas impacting children’s health: cancer, genomics and genetic diseases, neurobiology, and embryology. Our strong international reputation is based on decades of significant research outcomes in these areas of specialty. CMRI is also home to the world-first proteomics project, ProCan, which is changing the way cancer is diagnosed and treated. CMRI’s research programs are supported by state of the art facilities and committed research and support staff. Our achievements are made possible by a loyal network of community supporters, highly engaged donors, and the very successful Jeans for Genes® and Great Cycle Challenge fundraising campaigns.

Data Analysts, Data Scientists and Statistical & Mathematical Graduates
Multiple graduate opportunities across the Australian Government
Permanent positions


We are not currently accepting applications for the Australian Government Graduate Program - Data stream.

Register your interest here to receive updates on new Data Graduate positions as they become available.

What is the Australian Government Graduate Program - Data Stream?

The Australian Government Graduate Program - Data Stream is a program offering recent graduates permanent employment across the Australian Government. The Data Stream is led by the Australian Bureau of Statistics who recruit for data roles on behalf of the Australian Government.

One application for a Data Graduate position gives you access to opportunities across Australia in multiple agencies.

A wide range of data graduate roles will be recruited for, including Data Analysts, Data Scientists and Statistical & Mathematical roles.



Some of the agencies you may be able to work at include:

There are no requirements for any particular degrees or disciplines though graduates who have undertaken data related, statistics and maths subjects are more likely to be successful.



It's quick and easy to register your interest for upcoming positions. Once you have submitted your form, you'll go on our mailing list and we'll notify as soon as we have more information.

Job Title: EOI: Sessional/Casual Teaching Academic for Data Science
Job Description:
Our vision is to be a leading public university of technology recognised for our global impact. We are a dynamic and innovative university, ranked by QS Top 50 Under 50 rankings as Australia’s top young university, and located centrally in one of the world’s most liveable cities. With a culturally diverse campus life and extensive international exchange and research programs, UTS prepares graduates for the workplaces of today and tomorrow.
About the Role
Due to the rapid growth and increased popularity of our Data Science and Innovation program, a number of casual / sessional teaching roles (subject coordinator, lecturer and tutor) are available for the program at TD School. We are seeking expressions of interest from appropriately qualified and professionally experienced candidates to teach our data science subjects on a casual basis. Job Title: APS 4/5-6 (S&T Level 3-4) - Adversarial Machine Learning Researcher/Engineer
Job Description:
$71,207 - $97,790 (plus Super)
Edinburgh - SA


The Role
This role can be filled as either:
Adversarial Machine Learning Researcher.
Adversarial Machine Learning Engineer.

You will be part of an S&T team working in the area of Adversarial Machine Learning (AML) undertaking applied research, or engineering tasks, towards quantifying and enhancing the robustness of Machine Learning (ML) solutions for Defence applications.

AML involves countering data-driven attacks on ML solutions, whereby malicious actors modify training or test data to mislead and/or subvert ML predictions. You will help to devise, or implement and evaluate, new robust learning approaches suitable for adversarial environments and undertake research and development into the design and assessment of robust ML solutions for Defence applications, including reinforcement learning and deep learning.

Both roles are suitable for recent graduates and will expose the successful applicant to S&T challenges in cyber security and operations in a military context.

In addition, there exists the opportunity to work closely with Australian and international research partners, Defence clients and cyber security domain experts. You will also be supported with training in aspects of cyber security and ML as required, and encouraged to further develop your expertise.

The AML Researcher and AML Engineer, under guidance and as part of a multi-disciplinary team, will:

The AML Researcher will also be encouraged to engage with the scientific community.


The Information Sciences Division (ISD) leads Australia’s science and technology research associated with digital and electronic warfare threats in the information environment. The Division develops S&T to sense, interpret and shape the information environment to better understand, and assist in deterring and responding to, these threats through science and technology that helps shape, deter and respond to these digital and electromagnetic threats.

Within ISD, the Cyberwarfare Operations Branch (CWO) undertakes research and development to help Australian Defence develop an effective cyber warfare capability that enables fight-through in a contested cyber environment.

Within CWO, the Counter Cyber Threats group undertakes research and development to identify, understand and defeat threats to key cyber terrain. Their work supports ADF cyber operations, with a particular focus on defence of military mission systems and platform systems.


We are looking for candidates who can build and sustain positive relationships with team members, actively participate in team work and group activities, work collaboratively and operate as effective team members.

The ideal AML Researcher shall also be able to:

The ideal AML Engineer shall be able to:

60017771
The Bureau's Research Program sits within the Science and Innovation Group and is the main driver of world-class science-based innovation in the Bureau of Meteorology aligned with the Group’s R&D Plan 2020-2030. In supporting the Bureau to deliver impactful weather, water, climate, oceans and earth system prediction services, the research contributes to advancing meteorological and earth system sciences in Australia and globally. Research activities cover the broad fields of weather, climate, oceanography, land surface, and earth systems modelling, data set development, process studies, and application development.

The Hydrological Modelling team of the Bureau’s Research Program is seeking to fill the role of Scientist – Hydrologist (APS6). The successful candidate will contribute to the implementation and validation of the future operational continental routing scheme, as well as working with other scientists in the team to model the impact of soil hydrology and groundwater dynamics on the surface runoff generation. The successful candidate will take responsibility of the model verification within the Hydrological Modelling team and will closely collaborate with Hydrological Information and Surface Observations team, which leads the verification work within the section. Contribution to scientific discussions in support of the progression and definition of the Hydrological Modelling team’s main aims would be expected.

Tasks include developing plans to achieve milestones and overseeing their delivery within the designated work packages, including hands-on work on model data assessments, parameterisation of the routing schemes within continental-scale hydrological/land surface models, and if desired undertaking data assimilation experiments together with colleagues across the Research program, using scripting and coding languages (e.g. Python) on the Bureau’s and NCI’s Linux systems.

Where relevant, the Scientist – Hydrologist (APS6) will also contribute to initiatives of broader value to the entire Bureau (e.g. supporting the SIG leadership team with administrative tasks, actively engaging with social groups within the agency).

Job Title: EL 2 (S&T Level 6) - Research Specialist Software Vulnerabilities
Job Description:
$125,622 - $150,785 (plus Super)
Canberra - ACT


The Role
The Research Specialist Software Vulnerabilities will carry out scientific and technical research for program analysis of (source or binary) software of operational significance for Defence and National Security.

You will research and develop new program analysis techniques to be applied to software systems and work collaboratively with the Discipline Leader of Software Systems Security to maintain a world class team of software researcher and developers that discover, assess and defend against vulnerabilities across a diverse cyber landscape.

Duties and Key Result Areas:


The Cyber & Signals Intelligence (CSI) MSTC develops concepts, techniques and technologies for understanding cyberspace and the electromagnetic spectrum, supporting the intelligence and electronic surveillance needs of Defence.

CSI MSTC collaborates with a wide range of research organisations both nationally and internationally. CSI is primarily located at the DST Edinburgh site, with a presence also in Canberra.

Access Technologies (AT) undertakes R&D in technologies for cyber access and bespoke wireless communication, with a focus on physical layer RF communications and ICT system security.

The Software Systems Security Discipline in which this position resides, undertakes research and development that delivers advanced program analyses for discovering vulnerabilities in software. This includes reasoning about program behaviours and spans fundamental research to tools development for vulnerability research practitioners. Core skills within the discipline include dynamic, static and symbolic analysis underpinned by deep software engineering expertise.


Our ideal candidate will have a passion for program analysis applied to cyber security, with experience or aptitude in several of the following areas:
You will bring experience in the application of scientific techniques, with the ability to enhance Defence capabilities through innovation and collaboration with industry, academia and Government.

Job Title: Data Scientist - Procan Cancer Data Science (CDS)
Job Description:
Make an important contribution to the health of future generations through medical research
Work with a world-leading, independent medical research institute
Located in Westmead—Sydney’s and Australia’s foremost biomedical research precinct
Children’s Medical Research Institute (CMRI) was Australia’s first dedicated paediatric research facility and is now one of the world’s most highly regarded independent medical research organisations. Our research focuses on the four key areas impacting children’s health: cancer, genomics and genetic diseases, neurobiology, and embryology. Our strong international reputation is based on decades of significant research outcomes in these areas of specialty. CMRI is also home to the world-first proteomics project, ProCan, which is changing the way cancer is diagnosed and treated. CMRI’s research programs are supported by state of the art facilities and committed research and support staff. Our achievements are made possible by a loyal network of community supporters, highly engaged donors, and the very successful Jeans for Genes® and Great Cycle Challenge fundraising campaigns.

Job Title: APS 5, 6 (Multiple Classifications) - Geospatial Data Analyst / Geospatial Data Scientist
Job Description:
$78,143 - $97,790 (plus Super)
Russell - ACT
The Role
APS5/6 – Data Analyst

This role will leverage your understanding of statistics, Geospatial Information Systems (GIS), and programming. You will work as part of a team to develop and implement new tools and methodologies that use AGO’s data and GIS more effectively and efficiently. You will work with a range of stakeholders, including AGO’s intelligence analysts, data scientists and capability managers, ensuring your analytics meet user requirements, are rigorous and consistent with AGO’s system environment.

APS5/6 – Data Scientist

This role will leverage your experience in Machine Learning/Artificial Intelligence (ML/AI), data analysis and automation, to assist AGO to derive deeper insights from larger volumes of data, and at a pace that enables decision advantage. You will liaise with a range of stakeholders to evaluate and implement ML/AI technologies that drive innovation and modernise AGO’s analytic practices.

Both roles will support AGO staff to increase their digital and data fluency.


The Australian Geospatial-Intelligence Organisation (AGO) makes a critical contribution to protect the lives and safety of Australians at home and overseas by providing accurate and timely geospatial-intelligence to support decision makers at all levels.

The Data Innovation and Analytics Directorate (DIAD) is a team of highly motivated data specialists who provide analytical support to AGO’s intelligence and production areas. Our vision is to transform analytic workflows, increasing automation and augmentation through the application of data science and machine analytics. We work closely with a range of stakeholders to understand their analytic requirements, and deliver new tools and methodologies that enable them to achieve more efficient and innovative outcomes. We foster a data-driven culture that supports analysts to gain deeper insights from larger volumes of data. We provide opportunities for continuous learning and developing, including funding for tertiary qualifications in machine analytics, and the opportunity to engage with industry and academia.


Successful candidates will be highly motivated, have strong oral and communication skills, with broad knowledge of geospatial data applications and analytical techniques. In addition, they will be able to work both individually and as part of a team, build and maintain productive working relationships with diverse stakeholders, and proactively address skill/knowledge gaps.

They will be resilient problem solvers, willing to engage with ambiguity and are able to harness collective knowledge to optimise outcomes. They will also be possess some of the following:

The Bureau's Research Program sits within the Science and Innovation Group and is the main driver of world-class science-based innovation in the Bureau of Meteorology aligned with the Group’s R&D Plan 2020-2030. In supporting the Bureau to deliver impactful weather, water, climate, oceans and earth system prediction services, the research contributes to advancing meteorological and earth system sciences in Australia and globally. Research activities cover the broad fields of weather, climate, oceanography, land surface, and earth systems modelling, data set development, process studies, and application development.

The Hydrological Modelling team of the Bureau’s Research Program is seeking to fill the role of Scientist – Earth System Scientist. The successful candidate will lead novel research into hydrological and land surface dynamics modelling within the Hydrological Modelling team. A particular focus of this role is on the future operational land surface model’s re-parameterisation and verification (vegetation and soil physics) and in particular leading the Hydrological Modelling team’s work on the assimilation of new or novel observations into the land surface scheme. The successful candidate is also expected to contribute to discussions and take in part responsibility of the definition and progression of the Hydrological Modelling team’s main aims, using their understanding of customer needs.

The Earth System Scientist role is to lead relevant work packages within the Hydrological Modelling research program, and collaborate on select projects scientific and technical staff across the Research Program and other Bureau employees, as well as external stakeholders, in particular from the UK MetOffice and UK Centre for Environment and Hydrology. This requires the successful candidate to have experience in liaising effectively with such partners.
Tasks include developing research plans and overseeing their delivery within the designated work packages, including hands-on work on Earth observation data assessments, parameterisation of the land surface schemes within continental-scale hydrological/land surface models, and undertaking data assimilation experiments together with colleagues across the Research program, using scripting and coding languages (e.g. Python) on the Bureau’s and NCI’s Linux systems.

Where relevant, the Earth System Scientist will also contribute or lead strategic initiatives of broader value to the entire Bureau (e.g. the National Satellite Program on Earth Observations).

What is the Australian Government Graduate Program - Data Stream?

The Australian Government Graduate Program - Data Stream is a program offering recent graduates permanent employment across the Australian Government. The Data Stream is led by the Australian Bureau of Statistics who recruit for data roles on behalf of the Australian Government.

One application for a Data Graduate position gives you access to opportunities across Australia in multiple agencies.

A wide range of data graduate roles will be recruited for, including Data Analysts, Data Scientists and Statistical & Mathematical roles.



Some of the agencies you may be able to work at include:

There are no requirements for any particular degrees or disciplines though graduates who have undertaken data related, statistics and maths subjects are more likely to be successful.

Welcome to Aginic, a consultancy where some of the country’s brightest data analysts, engineers, agile coaches, designers, and cloud architects blend their technical skills with a desire to deliver impactful insights that solve business problems.

The Bureau's Research Program sits within the Science and Innovation Group and is the main driver of world-class science-based innovation in the Bureau of Meteorology aligned with the Group’s R&D Plan 2020-2030. In supporting the Bureau to deliver impactful weather, water, climate, oceans and earth system prediction services, the research contributes to advancing meteorological and earth system sciences in Australia and globally. Research activities cover the broad fields of weather, climate, oceanography, land surface, and earth systems modelling, data set development, process studies, and application development.

The Hydrological Modelling team of the Bureau’s Research Program is seeking to fill the role of Scientist – Hydrologist (APS6). The successful candidate will contribute to the implementation and validation of the future operational continental routing scheme, as well as working with other scientists in the team to model the impact of soil hydrology and groundwater dynamics on the surface runoff generation. The successful candidate will take responsibility of the model verification within the Hydrological Modelling team and will closely collaborate with Hydrological Information and Surface Observations team, which leads the verification work within the section. Contribution to scientific discussions in support of the progression and definition of the Hydrological Modelling team’s main aims would be expected.

Tasks include developing plans to achieve milestones and overseeing their delivery within the designated work packages, including hands-on work on model data assessments, parameterisation of the routing schemes within continental-scale hydrological/land surface models, and if desired undertaking data assimilation experiments together with colleagues across the Research program, using scripting and coding languages (e.g. Python) on the Bureau’s and NCI’s Linux systems.

Where relevant, the Scientist – Hydrologist (APS6) will also contribute to initiatives of broader value to the entire Bureau (e.g. supporting the SIG leadership team with administrative tasks, actively engaging with social groups within the agency).

Job Title: EL 2 (S&T Level 6) - Research Specialist Software Vulnerabilities
Job Description:
$125,622 - $150,785 (plus Super)
Canberra - ACT


The Role
The Research Specialist Software Vulnerabilities will carry out scientific and technical research for program analysis of (source or binary) software of operational significance for Defence and National Security.

You will research and develop new program analysis techniques to be applied to software systems and work collaboratively with the Discipline Leader of Software Systems Security to maintain a world class team of software researcher and developers that discover, assess and defend against vulnerabilities across a diverse cyber landscape.

Duties and Key Result Areas:


The Cyber & Signals Intelligence (CSI) MSTC develops concepts, techniques and technologies for understanding cyberspace and the electromagnetic spectrum, supporting the intelligence and electronic surveillance needs of Defence.

CSI MSTC collaborates with a wide range of research organisations both nationally and internationally. CSI is primarily located at the DST Edinburgh site, with a presence also in Canberra.

Access Technologies (AT) undertakes R&D in technologies for cyber access and bespoke wireless communication, with a focus on physical layer RF communications and ICT system security.

The Software Systems Security Discipline in which this position resides, undertakes research and development that delivers advanced program analyses for discovering vulnerabilities in software. This includes reasoning about program behaviours and spans fundamental research to tools development for vulnerability research practitioners. Core skills within the discipline include dynamic, static and symbolic analysis underpinned by deep software engineering expertise.


Our ideal candidate will have a passion for program analysis applied to cyber security, with experience or aptitude in several of the following areas:
You will bring experience in the application of scientific techniques, with the ability to enhance Defence capabilities through innovation and collaboration with industry, academia and Government.

You will have the following:

Company Description
Minderoo Foundation is a modern philanthropic organisation. We take on tough, persistent issues with the potential to drive massive change. We incubate ideas and accelerate impact. We push the limits of what is believed possible. Minderoo Foundation is independent, forward thinking and seeks effective, scalable solutions. We are proudly Australian, and one of Asia’s largest philanthropies, with AUD $2 billion committed to a range of global initiatives. Our team comprises over 150 employees across seven locations.
Walk Free is an international human rights group working to accelerate the end of all forms of modern slavery. We combine world class research with engagement with political, business, religious and community leaders and direct implementation through our civil society partners to drive systems change and dismantle the drivers of modern slavery.

Job Title: APS 4/5-6 (S&T Level 3-4) - Adversarial Machine Learning Researcher/Engineer
Job Description:
$71,207 - $97,790 (plus Super)
Edinburgh - SA


The Role
This role can be filled as either:
Adversarial Machine Learning Researcher.
Adversarial Machine Learning Engineer.

You will be part of an S&T team working in the area of Adversarial Machine Learning (AML) undertaking applied research, or engineering tasks, towards quantifying and enhancing the robustness of Machine Learning (ML) solutions for Defence applications.

AML involves countering data-driven attacks on ML solutions, whereby malicious actors modify training or test data to mislead and/or subvert ML predictions. You will help to devise, or implement and evaluate, new robust learning approaches suitable for adversarial environments and undertake research and development into the design and assessment of robust ML solutions for Defence applications, including reinforcement learning and deep learning.

Both roles are suitable for recent graduates and will expose the successful applicant to S&T challenges in cyber security and operations in a military context.

In addition, there exists the opportunity to work closely with Australian and international research partners, Defence clients and cyber security domain experts. You will also be supported with training in aspects of cyber security and ML as required, and encouraged to further develop your expertise.

The AML Researcher and AML Engineer, under guidance and as part of a multi-disciplinary team, will:

The AML Researcher will also be encouraged to engage with the scientific community.


The Information Sciences Division (ISD) leads Australia’s science and technology research associated with digital and electronic warfare threats in the information environment. The Division develops S&T to sense, interpret and shape the information environment to better understand, and assist in deterring and responding to, these threats through science and technology that helps shape, deter and respond to these digital and electromagnetic threats.

Within ISD, the Cyberwarfare Operations Branch (CWO) undertakes research and development to help Australian Defence develop an effective cyber warfare capability that enables fight-through in a contested cyber environment.

Within CWO, the Counter Cyber Threats group undertakes research and development to identify, understand and defeat threats to key cyber terrain. Their work supports ADF cyber operations, with a particular focus on defence of military mission systems and platform systems.


We are looking for candidates who can build and sustain positive relationships with team members, actively participate in team work and group activities, work collaboratively and operate as effective team members.

The ideal AML Researcher shall also be able to:

The ideal AML Engineer shall be able to:

About the Role
AB MAURI is a global family of yeast and bakery ingredient companies and one of the largest producers and distributors in the world, striving to be the leaders of innovation within the industry. With over 6,000 employees working across 52 plants, operations in 32 countries and sales in over 100 countries, AB MAURI is Associated British Foods' (ABF) most globally represented business.
We have an excellent opportunity available for a qualified Culture Collection Microbiologist to join the Culture Collection Team at our Global Technology Centre in North Ryde.
The AB Mauri Culture Collection Team, reporting to the Culture Collection Team Leader, is responsible for the maintenance of the expanding AB Mauri culture collection. This team supports both the global yeast plants (providing certified starter cultures to ensure product quality) and the Research & Development team providing cultures as the basis of new technology development. As new strains are obtained from internal and external sources the Culture Collection team ensure the identity and quality of the cultures before entering them into the collated AB Mauri Culture Collection.
What's in it for you?
This role will give you the opportunity to work with multidisciplinary and geographically diverse teams and be exposed to the development and deployment of industrially significant biotechnology products.
You will work alongside a dedicated and collaborative team of Technicians from other disciplines, who regularly support one another in the completion of their projects.
This is a fantastic opportunity to develop your career a highly reputable global business.
About you
To be considered for the role, it is essential that you have a Bachelor of Science with majors in Microbiology, Biotechnology, Molecular Biology or Fermentation Science.


Previous experience in Yeast microbiology, genetic techniques and Yeast strain assessment would be an advantage.
These are some of the abilities we will be looking for you to demonstrate:

Job Title: APS 5, 6 (Multiple Classifications) - Geospatial Data Analyst / Geospatial Data Scientist
Job Description:
$78,143 - $97,790 (plus Super)
Russell - ACT
The Role
APS5/6 – Data Analyst

This role will leverage your understanding of statistics, Geospatial Information Systems (GIS), and programming. You will work as part of a team to develop and implement new tools and methodologies that use AGO’s data and GIS more effectively and efficiently. You will work with a range of stakeholders, including AGO’s intelligence analysts, data scientists and capability managers, ensuring your analytics meet user requirements, are rigorous and consistent with AGO’s system environment.

APS5/6 – Data Scientist

This role will leverage your experience in Machine Learning/Artificial Intelligence (ML/AI), data analysis and automation, to assist AGO to derive deeper insights from larger volumes of data, and at a pace that enables decision advantage. You will liaise with a range of stakeholders to evaluate and implement ML/AI technologies that drive innovation and modernise AGO’s analytic practices.

Both roles will support AGO staff to increase their digital and data fluency.


The Australian Geospatial-Intelligence Organisation (AGO) makes a critical contribution to protect the lives and safety of Australians at home and overseas by providing accurate and timely geospatial-intelligence to support decision makers at all levels.

The Data Innovation and Analytics Directorate (DIAD) is a team of highly motivated data specialists who provide analytical support to AGO’s intelligence and production areas. Our vision is to transform analytic workflows, increasing automation and augmentation through the application of data science and machine analytics. We work closely with a range of stakeholders to understand their analytic requirements, and deliver new tools and methodologies that enable them to achieve more efficient and innovative outcomes. We foster a data-driven culture that supports analysts to gain deeper insights from larger volumes of data. We provide opportunities for continuous learning and developing, including funding for tertiary qualifications in machine analytics, and the opportunity to engage with industry and academia.


Successful candidates will be highly motivated, have strong oral and communication skills, with broad knowledge of geospatial data applications and analytical techniques. In addition, they will be able to work both individually and as part of a team, build and maintain productive working relationships with diverse stakeholders, and proactively address skill/knowledge gaps.

They will be resilient problem solvers, willing to engage with ambiguity and are able to harness collective knowledge to optimise outcomes. They will also be possess some of the following:

Job Title: Data Scientist - Procan Cancer Data Science (CDS)
Job Description:
Make an important contribution to the health of future generations through medical research
Work with a world-leading, independent medical research institute
Located in Westmead—Sydney’s and Australia’s foremost biomedical research precinct
Children’s Medical Research Institute (CMRI) was Australia’s first dedicated paediatric research facility and is now one of the world’s most highly regarded independent medical research organisations. Our research focuses on the four key areas impacting children’s health: cancer, genomics and genetic diseases, neurobiology, and embryology. Our strong international reputation is based on decades of significant research outcomes in these areas of specialty. CMRI is also home to the world-first proteomics project, ProCan, which is changing the way cancer is diagnosed and treated. CMRI’s research programs are supported by state of the art facilities and committed research and support staff. Our achievements are made possible by a loyal network of community supporters, highly engaged donors, and the very successful Jeans for Genes® and Great Cycle Challenge fundraising campaigns.

Executive Level 2 (SRS) - Ongoing
$125,053 - $146,999 + 15.4% super
Any Bureau’s State or Territory capital city office
The Bureau's Research Program sits within the Science and Innovation Group and is the main driver of world-class science-based innovation in the Bureau of Meteorology aligned with the Group’s R&D Plan 2020-2030. In supporting the Bureau to deliver impactful weather, water, climate, oceans and earth system prediction services, the research contributes to advancing meteorological and earth system sciences in Australia and globally. Research activities cover the broad fields of weather, climate, oceanography, land surface, and earth systems modelling, data set development, process studies, and application development.

The Hydrological Modelling team of the Bureau’s Research Program is seeking to fill the role of Scientist – Earth System Scientist. The successful candidate will lead novel research into hydrological and land surface dynamics modelling within the Hydrological Modelling team. A particular focus of this role is on the future operational land surface model’s re-parameterisation and verification (vegetation and soil physics) and in particular leading the Hydrological Modelling team’s work on the assimilation of new or novel observations into the land surface scheme. The successful candidate is also expected to contribute to discussions and take in part responsibility of the definition and progression of the Hydrological Modelling team’s main aims, using their understanding of customer needs.

The Earth System Scientist role is to lead relevant work packages within the Hydrological Modelling research program, and collaborate on select projects scientific and technical staff across the Research Program and other Bureau employees, as well as external stakeholders, in particular from the UK MetOffice and UK Centre for Environment and Hydrology. This requires the successful candidate to have experience in liaising effectively with such partners.
Tasks include developing research plans and overseeing their delivery within the designated work packages, including hands-on work on Earth observation data assessments, parameterisation of the land surface schemes within continental-scale hydrological/land surface models, and undertaking data assimilation experiments together with colleagues across the Research program, using scripting and coding languages (e.g. Python) on the Bureau’s and NCI’s Linux systems.

Where relevant, the Earth System Scientist will also contribute or lead strategic initiatives of broader value to the entire Bureau (e.g. the National Satellite Program on Earth Observations).

What is the Australian Government Graduate Program - Data Stream?

The Australian Government Graduate Program - Data Stream is a program offering recent graduates permanent employment across the Australian Government. The Data Stream is led by the Australian Bureau of Statistics who recruit for data roles on behalf of the Australian Government.

One application for a Data Graduate position gives you access to opportunities across Australia in multiple agencies.

A wide range of data graduate roles will be recruited for, including Data Analysts, Data Scientists and Statistical & Mathematical roles.



Some of the agencies you may be able to work at include:

There are no requirements for any particular degrees or disciplines though graduates who have undertaken data related, statistics and maths subjects are more likely to be successful.

We won’t give you a career path – we’ll help you shape your own. It’s your time to explore and advance in the areas you find inspirational. Expect purpose, progression and to make an impact that matters. Your story is only just beginning, and your green dot is what you make of it.

Job Title: APS 4/5-6 (S&T Level 3-4) - Adversarial Machine Learning Researcher/Engineer
Job Description:
$71,207 - $97,790 (plus Super)
Edinburgh - SA


The Role
This role can be filled as either:
Adversarial Machine Learning Researcher.
Adversarial Machine Learning Engineer.

You will be part of an S&T team working in the area of Adversarial Machine Learning (AML) undertaking applied research, or engineering tasks, towards quantifying and enhancing the robustness of Machine Learning (ML) solutions for Defence applications.

AML involves countering data-driven attacks on ML solutions, whereby malicious actors modify training or test data to mislead and/or subvert ML predictions. You will help to devise, or implement and evaluate, new robust learning approaches suitable for adversarial environments and undertake research and development into the design and assessment of robust ML solutions for Defence applications, including reinforcement learning and deep learning.

Both roles are suitable for recent graduates and will expose the successful applicant to S&T challenges in cyber security and operations in a military context.

In addition, there exists the opportunity to work closely with Australian and international research partners, Defence clients and cyber security domain experts. You will also be supported with training in aspects of cyber security and ML as required, and encouraged to further develop your expertise.

The AML Researcher and AML Engineer, under guidance and as part of a multi-disciplinary team, will:

The AML Researcher will also be encouraged to engage with the scientific community.


The Information Sciences Division (ISD) leads Australia’s science and technology research associated with digital and electronic warfare threats in the information environment. The Division develops S&T to sense, interpret and shape the information environment to better understand, and assist in deterring and responding to, these threats through science and technology that helps shape, deter and respond to these digital and electromagnetic threats.

Within ISD, the Cyberwarfare Operations Branch (CWO) undertakes research and development to help Australian Defence develop an effective cyber warfare capability that enables fight-through in a contested cyber environment.

Within CWO, the Counter Cyber Threats group undertakes research and development to identify, understand and defeat threats to key cyber terrain. Their work supports ADF cyber operations, with a particular focus on defence of military mission systems and platform systems.


We are looking for candidates who can build and sustain positive relationships with team members, actively participate in team work and group activities, work collaboratively and operate as effective team members.

The ideal AML Researcher shall also be able to:

We are proudly Australian, and one of Asia’s largest philanthropies, with AUD $2 billion committed to a range of global initiatives. Our team comprises over 150 employees across seven locations.
Walk Free is an international human rights group working to accelerate the end of all forms of modern slavery. We combine world class research with engagement with political, business, religious and community leaders and direct implementation through our civil society partners to drive systems change and dismantle the drivers of modern slavery.

Analyse qualitative and quantitative research and social media data, applying problem-solving skills to draw insights into sentiment, challenges and opportunities, and work with senior leadership to suggest actions to inform communications decisions and campaigns

Job Title: EL 2 (S&T Level 6) - Research Specialist Software Vulnerabilities
Job Description:
$125,622 - $150,785 (plus Super)
Canberra - ACT


The Role
The Research Specialist Software Vulnerabilities will carry out scientific and technical research for program analysis of (source or binary) software of operational significance for Defence and National Security.

You will research and develop new program analysis techniques to be applied to software systems and work collaboratively with the Discipline Leader of Software Systems Security to maintain a world class team of software researcher and developers that discover, assess and defend against vulnerabilities across a diverse cyber landscape.

Duties and Key Result Areas:


The Cyber & Signals Intelligence (CSI) MSTC develops concepts, techniques and technologies for understanding cyberspace and the electromagnetic spectrum, supporting the intelligence and electronic surveillance needs of Defence.

CSI MSTC collaborates with a wide range of research organisations both nationally and internationally. CSI is primarily located at the DST Edinburgh site, with a presence also in Canberra.

Access Technologies (AT) undertakes R&D in technologies for cyber access and bespoke wireless communication, with a focus on physical layer RF communications and ICT system security.

The Software Systems Security Discipline in which this position resides, undertakes research and development that delivers advanced program analyses for discovering vulnerabilities in software. This includes reasoning about program behaviours and spans fundamental research to tools development for vulnerability research practitioners. Core skills within the discipline include dynamic, static and symbolic analysis underpinned by deep software engineering expertise.


Our ideal candidate will have a passion for program analysis applied to cyber security, with experience or aptitude in several of the following areas:
You will bring experience in the application of scientific techniques, with the ability to enhance Defence capabilities through innovation and collaboration with industry, academia and Government.

$84,417 - $95,979 + 15.4% super
60017771
The Bureau's Research Program sits within the Science and Innovation Group and is the main driver of world-class science-based innovation in the Bureau of Meteorology aligned with the Group’s R&D Plan 2020-2030. In supporting the Bureau to deliver impactful weather, water, climate, oceans and earth system prediction services, the research contributes to advancing meteorological and earth system sciences in Australia and globally. Research activities cover the broad fields of weather, climate, oceanography, land surface, and earth systems modelling, data set development, process studies, and application development.

The Hydrological Modelling team of the Bureau’s Research Program is seeking to fill the role of Scientist – Hydrologist (APS6). The successful candidate will contribute to the implementation and validation of the future operational continental routing scheme, as well as working with other scientists in the team to model the impact of soil hydrology and groundwater dynamics on the surface runoff generation. The successful candidate will take responsibility of the model verification within the Hydrological Modelling team and will closely collaborate with Hydrological Information and Surface Observations team, which leads the verification work within the section. Contribution to scientific discussions in support of the progression and definition of the Hydrological Modelling team’s main aims would be expected.

Tasks include developing plans to achieve milestones and overseeing their delivery within the designated work packages, including hands-on work on model data assessments, parameterisation of the routing schemes within continental-scale hydrological/land surface models, and if desired undertaking data assimilation experiments together with colleagues across the Research program, using scripting and coding languages (e.g. Python) on the Bureau’s and NCI’s Linux systems.

Where relevant, the Scientist – Hydrologist (APS6) will also contribute to initiatives of broader value to the entire Bureau (e.g. supporting the SIG leadership team with administrative tasks, actively engaging with social groups within the agency).

Job Title: Data Scientist - Procan Cancer Data Science (CDS)
Job Description:
Make an important contribution to the health of future generations through medical research
Work with a world-leading, independent medical research institute
Located in Westmead—Sydney’s and Australia’s foremost biomedical research precinct
Children’s Medical Research Institute (CMRI) was Australia’s first dedicated paediatric research facility and is now one of the world’s most highly regarded independent medical research organisations. Our research focuses on the four key areas impacting children’s health: cancer, genomics and genetic diseases, neurobiology, and embryology. Our strong international reputation is based on decades of significant research outcomes in these areas of specialty. CMRI is also home to the world-first proteomics project, ProCan, which is changing the way cancer is diagnosed and treated. CMRI’s research programs are supported by state of the art facilities and committed research and support staff. Our achievements are made possible by a loyal network of community supporters, highly engaged donors, and the very successful Jeans for Genes® and Great Cycle Challenge fundraising campaigns.

Job Title: APS 5, 6 (Multiple Classifications) - Geospatial Data Analyst / Geospatial Data Scientist
Job Description:
$78,143 - $97,790 (plus Super)
Russell - ACT
The Role
APS5/6 – Data Analyst

This role will leverage your understanding of statistics, Geospatial Information Systems (GIS), and programming. You will work as part of a team to develop and implement new tools and methodologies that use AGO’s data and GIS more effectively and efficiently. You will work with a range of stakeholders, including AGO’s intelligence analysts, data scientists and capability managers, ensuring your analytics meet user requirements, are rigorous and consistent with AGO’s system environment.

APS5/6 – Data Scientist

This role will leverage your experience in Machine Learning/Artificial Intelligence (ML/AI), data analysis and automation, to assist AGO to derive deeper insights from larger volumes of data, and at a pace that enables decision advantage. You will liaise with a range of stakeholders to evaluate and implement ML/AI technologies that drive innovation and modernise AGO’s analytic practices.

Both roles will support AGO staff to increase their digital and data fluency.


The Australian Geospatial-Intelligence Organisation (AGO) makes a critical contribution to protect the lives and safety of Australians at home and overseas by providing accurate and timely geospatial-intelligence to support decision makers at all levels.

The Data Innovation and Analytics Directorate (DIAD) is a team of highly motivated data specialists who provide analytical support to AGO’s intelligence and production areas. Our vision is to transform analytic workflows, increasing automation and augmentation through the application of data science and machine analytics. We work closely with a range of stakeholders to understand their analytic requirements, and deliver new tools and methodologies that enable them to achieve more efficient and innovative outcomes. We foster a data-driven culture that supports analysts to gain deeper insights from larger volumes of data. We provide opportunities for continuous learning and developing, including funding for tertiary qualifications in machine analytics, and the opportunity to engage with industry and academia.


Successful candidates will be highly motivated, have strong oral and communication skills, with broad knowledge of geospatial data applications and analytical techniques. In addition, they will be able to work both individually and as part of a team, build and maintain productive working relationships with diverse stakeholders, and proactively address skill/knowledge gaps.

They will be resilient problem solvers, willing to engage with ambiguity and are able to harness collective knowledge to optimise outcomes. They will also be possess some of the following:

The Bureau's Research Program sits within the Science and Innovation Group and is the main driver of world-class science-based innovation in the Bureau of Meteorology aligned with the Group’s R&D Plan 2020-2030. In supporting the Bureau to deliver impactful weather, water, climate, oceans and earth system prediction services, the research contributes to advancing meteorological and earth system sciences in Australia and globally. Research activities cover the broad fields of weather, climate, oceanography, land surface, and earth systems modelling, data set development, process studies, and application development.

The Hydrological Modelling team of the Bureau’s Research Program is seeking to fill the role of Scientist – Earth System Scientist. The successful candidate will lead novel research into hydrological and land surface dynamics modelling within the Hydrological Modelling team. A particular focus of this role is on the future operational land surface model’s re-parameterisation and verification (vegetation and soil physics) and in particular leading the Hydrological Modelling team’s work on the assimilation of new or novel observations into the land surface scheme. The successful candidate is also expected to contribute to discussions and take in part responsibility of the definition and progression of the Hydrological Modelling team’s main aims, using their understanding of customer needs.

The Earth System Scientist role is to lead relevant work packages within the Hydrological Modelling research program, and collaborate on select projects scientific and technical staff across the Research Program and other Bureau employees, as well as external stakeholders, in particular from the UK MetOffice and UK Centre for Environment and Hydrology. This requires the successful candidate to have experience in liaising effectively with such partners.
Tasks include developing research plans and overseeing their delivery within the designated work packages, including hands-on work on Earth observation data assessments, parameterisation of the land surface schemes within continental-scale hydrological/land surface models, and undertaking data assimilation experiments together with colleagues across the Research program, using scripting and coding languages (e.g. Python) on the Bureau’s and NCI’s Linux systems.

Where relevant, the Earth System Scientist will also contribute or lead strategic initiatives of broader value to the entire Bureau (e.g. the National Satellite Program on Earth Observations).

Why Deloitte?

We call ourselves a professional services firm – but really, we’re a group of inspired individuals tackling the biggest challenges facing Australia today.

Whether you’re a disruptor, creator or decision-maker – find the path for your purpose and help shape a better tomorrow with us here at Deloitte.

Awarded Australia Financial Review’s Top 100 Graduate Employer and Most Popular Technology Employer in 2020.

Inclusion, Diversity & Wellbeing

We’re committed to continually building a diverse and respectful workplace where all our people feel appreciated and accepted. Through the creation of endorsed employee-led diversity networks which promote culture, disability, LGBTI+, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and gender equality, we’re leading the way to shape an environment where everybody can thrive. Data Analysts, Data Scientists and Statistical & Mathematical Graduates
Multiple graduate opportunities across the Australian Government
Permanent positions


We are not currently accepting applications for the Australian Government Graduate Program - Data stream.

Register your interest here to receive updates on new Data Graduate positions as they become available.

What is the Australian Government Graduate Program - Data Stream?

The Australian Government Graduate Program - Data Stream is a program offering recent graduates permanent employment across the Australian Government. The Data Stream is led by the Australian Bureau of Statistics who recruit for data roles on behalf of the Australian Government.

One application for a Data Graduate position gives you access to opportunities across Australia in multiple agencies.

A wide range of data graduate roles will be recruited for, including Data Analysts, Data Scientists and Statistical & Mathematical roles.



Some of the agencies you may be able to work at include:

There are no requirements for any particular degrees or disciplines though graduates who have undertaken data related, statistics and maths subjects are more likely to be successful.



It's quick and easy to register your interest for upcoming positions. Once you have submitted your form, you'll go on our mailing list and we'll notify as soon as we have more information.

Job Description:
$78,143 - $83,700 (plus Super)
Fairbairn - ACT
The Role
Do you enjoy working with a diverse range of people?
Are you interested in joining a great workplace in a challenging and rewarding role?
Do you have information management experience?

You will be responsible for the management of all information required to support program governance and decision support activity in the newly created Innovation, Science and Technology (IS&T) Capability Program Management Office (PgMO).

You will work closely with the Deputy Director PgMO - Governance and Decision Support, the Program Decision Support Analysis lead and contractor support to:


The IS&T Capability Program is responsible for delivering the agile defence innovation system and research infrastructure that will enable Defence to develop its future capability edge.

The IS&T Capability Program Management Office (PgMO) provides the Chief Defence Scientist and IS&T Capability Program executives with the support they need to make timely decisions and drive program performance. In this critical enabling role, the PgMO supports all IS&T Capability Program governance and is responsible for driving adoption of new programmatic ways of delivering capability in DSTG.

The PgMO also supports integration with other programs and DSTG elements, and coordinates and delivers support and guidance to the IS&T Projects that deliver many of those outcomes.


A team player who thrives in a fast paced, often ambiguous environment.

As the Program Information Management Support officer, you will have information management and/or project support office experience, an eagerness to learn, be detail orientated, with the ability to effectively prioritise tasks.

We are a small team, so you will need to:

APS Level 6, Ongoing/Non-ongoing
$84,417 - $95,979 + 15.4% super
60017771
The Bureau's Research Program sits within the Science and Innovation Group and is the main driver of world-class science-based innovation in the Bureau of Meteorology aligned with the Group’s R&D Plan 2020-2030. In supporting the Bureau to deliver impactful weather, water, climate, oceans and earth system prediction services, the research contributes to advancing meteorological and earth system sciences in Australia and globally. Research activities cover the broad fields of weather, climate, oceanography, land surface, and earth systems modelling, data set development, process studies, and application development.

The Hydrological Modelling team of the Bureau’s Research Program is seeking to fill the role of Scientist – Hydrologist (APS6). The successful candidate will contribute to the implementation and validation of the future operational continental routing scheme, as well as working with other scientists in the team to model the impact of soil hydrology and groundwater dynamics on the surface runoff generation. The successful candidate will take responsibility of the model verification within the Hydrological Modelling team and will closely collaborate with Hydrological Information and Surface Observations team, which leads the verification work within the section. Contribution to scientific discussions in support of the progression and definition of the Hydrological Modelling team’s main aims would be expected.

Tasks include developing plans to achieve milestones and overseeing their delivery within the designated work packages, including hands-on work on model data assessments, parameterisation of the routing schemes within continental-scale hydrological/land surface models, and if desired undertaking data assimilation experiments together with colleagues across the Research program, using scripting and coding languages (e.g. Python) on the Bureau’s and NCI’s Linux systems.

Where relevant, the Scientist – Hydrologist (APS6) will also contribute to initiatives of broader value to the entire Bureau (e.g. supporting the SIG leadership team with administrative tasks, actively engaging with social groups within the agency).

Job Title: , Research Fellow in Edge Computing, School of Computer, Data and Mathematical Sciences
Job Description:
Full-time, fixed term until 30 September 2023
Remuneration: $127,812 to $150,817 p.a.
Parramatta South campus
About Western
Western Sydney University is a modern, forward-thinking, research-led university, located at the heart of Australia’s fastest-growing and economically significant region, Western Sydney. Boasting 11 campuses – many in Western Sydney CBD locations – and more than 200,000 alumni, 49,500 students and 3,500 staff, the University has 14 Schools with an array of well-designed programs and degrees carefully structured to meet the demands of future industry. Western Sydney University is a modern, forward-thinking, research-led university, located at the heart of Australia’s fastest-growing economically significant region, Western Sydney.

Benefits
Western Sydney University has long been identified as a University of the people. We value the contributions made by our staff and recognise that they underpin the enablement of our mission and values. In return, we offer:


The School of Computer, Data and Mathematical Sciences is located in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) Cluster, together with the School of Engineering, Design and Built Environment, the School of Science, the MARCS Institute and the Hawkesbury Institute for the Environment.

The School offers both undergraduate and postgraduate programs, including research programs that combine advanced academic knowledge with real-life training to suit a range of career needs and interests in the following disciplines: Computer Science and Information Technologies, Data Sciences and Mathematics. The School conducts world leading research in main themes including Intelligent Decision Making, Computing for Sustainability and Equality and Foundation, Algorithms and Discovery.

We seek an energetic, forward-thinking, dynamic, and innovative scholar to take on a Postdoctoral Research Fellowship for a full-time, fixed-term role for one year to work on On-Board Federated Learning in Orbital Edge Computing for Space Situational Awareness. The appointed applicant will undertake research in Edge Computing focusing on federated learning and reconfigurable computing.


The successful applicant is expected to be developing a strong international standing and research reputation, have an excellent research background in the field of edge computing and machine learning, have demonstrated track record of publication of high-quality papers in top journals and conferences in the field, and capacity to undertake independent research.

The position is a full-time, fixed term role until 30 September 2023, based at the Parramatta South Campus.

Please refer to the position description for more information.
